G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Somerville, Middlesex County, and the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the District Court Department.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Somerville, Middlesex County, and the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the District Court Department.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: The existence of such duty is well-established under Massachusetts law, including but not limited to Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (abolishing distinctions between invitees and licensees and recognizing duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the common-law distinctions between invitees and licensees and imposing a general duty of reasonable care toward all lawful entrants. The quoted concurring passage expressly acknowledges that the court’s opinion rejects the invitee/licensee categories and instead bases an occupier’s responsibility on more substantive factors. Although this excerpt focuses on concerns about trespassers, it is consistent with and presupposes the holding described in the proposition regarding lawful visitors.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. … Thus it is awkward to leave the suggestion that the basic reasoning of the court’s opinion may stop short of so called trespassers."

Massachusetts General Laws c. 231, \u00a.proposition: Under Massachusetts General Laws c. 231, § 85, a plaintiff injured by reason of another’s negligence may recover damages reduced only by her own comparative fault, if any.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Property owners and occupiers owe a duty of reasonable care to maintain safe premises.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses premises liability and expressly states that a property owner owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition. The court’s holding abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction precisely in order to apply the general duty of reasonable care to hazards from snow and ice, confirming that owners and occupiers have such a duty regarding premises safety.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property … the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Property owners and occupiers owe a duty of reasonable care to maintain safe premises.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the duty owed by one who controls business premises to its patrons: to use due care to keep the premises reasonably safe or to warn of non-obvious dangers of which the defendant knows or should know. That is a straightforward articulation of a duty of reasonable care in premises liability, matching the claimed proposition about property owners/occupiers owing a duty to maintain safe premises.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: A defendant is liable where it knew or should have known of a hazardous condition and failed to act within a reasonable time.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion describes the traditional rule that imposes liability when a defendant knew or should have known of a hazardous condition and failed to act within a reasonable time, but the case’s holding expressly moves away from that notice-based standard. The court adopts the “mode of operation” approach, under which proof of a reasonably foreseeable risk inherent in the defendant’s business can substitute for proof that the defendant knew or should have known of the specific hazard. Thus, the case does not support the proposition as a governing liability rule; it refines and partially displaces it in this context.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, the adoption of the mode of operation approach will not modify the general rule governing premises liability requiring a plaintiff to prove that an owner had either actual or constructive notice of an unsafe condition on the premises. However, if a plaintiff proves that an unsafe condition on an owner’s premises exists that was reasonably foreseeable, resulting from an owner’s self-service business or mode of operation, and the plaintiff slips as a result of the unsafe condition, the plaintiff will satisfy the notice requirement.”

Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Thurlow v. Shaw’s Supermarkets, Inc., 49 Mass. App. Ct. 175 (2000)
Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: A defendant is liable where it knew or should have known of a hazardous condition and failed to act within a reasonable time.
Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the duty of a business owner to keep premises reasonably safe and to warn of dangers the owner knows or ought to know about, and it affirms liability based on constructive notice where water from melting ice had been present long enough that employees reasonably should have discovered and remedied it. The court upholds the trial judge’s finding that Shaw’s “reasonably should have been aware” of the water for almost two hours and thus was negligent in not acting within that time, which matches the proposition that liability attaches when a defendant knew or should have known of a hazard and failed to act within a reasonable time.
Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “One who controls business premises has an obligation ‘to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.’… Based upon that time frame, the obvious nature of the melting, and the fact that at least one store employee was near, the judge concluded that the defendant had constructive notice of the hazard… ‘someone at Shaw’s reasonably should have been aware of this amount of water on the floor in front of the fish display case [for almost two hours].’”}

Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.raw_text: Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560 (1955)
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.proposition: Constructive notice of a dangerous condition may be inferred when the hazard existed for an appreciable time or was identifiable upon reasonable inspection.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses constructive notice, holding that the store may be liable if the foreign substance was present long enough that, in the exercise of reasonable care and inspection by nearby cashiers, the condition should have been discovered and removed. The court explicitly infers notice from the appreciable time needed for the ice cream to reach its dirty, tracked-on condition and from its visibility to employees stationed nearby. This aligns directly with the proposition that constructive notice can be inferred from a hazard’s appreciable duration or detectability on reasonable inspection.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance.… The record shows that the ice cream must have come upon the floor within the period of thirty minutes… Some appreciable time must have elapsed also for the ice cream to have gotten into the condition it was in after the accident as described by the plaintiff.… [T]he jury were warranted in drawing an inference… that it had been on the stairway long enough to have been known of and removed before the accident.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: Constructive notice of a dangerous condition may be inferred when the hazard existed for an appreciable time or was identifiable upon reasonable inspection.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses constructive notice in a slip-and-fall context and expressly states that, absent proof the defendant created the condition or had actual knowledge, the plaintiff must show the hazard existed long enough that it should have been discovered and remedied by reasonable inspection. The court then analyzes both the duration of the condition and the opportunity for discovery, and finds the evidence insufficient, thereby affirming the principle that constructive notice may be inferred from an appreciable time plus discoverability upon reasonable care.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers… The decisive issues, therefore, are the length of time the condition is present and the opportunity for discovery on the facts of the case.”

Vaisbord v. Boston Edison Co., 304 Mass..raw_text: Vaisbord v. Boston Edison Co., 304 Mass. 60 (1939)
Vaisbord v. Boston Edison Co., 304 Mass..proposition: A store employee’s knowledge of a spill is imputable to the store.
Vaisbord v. Boston Edison Co., 304 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an accounting dispute between estates involving trust distributions and joint bank accounts between a husband and wife. It does not involve premises liability, spills, store employees, or imputation of an employee’s knowledge to a store. Nothing in the holding or reasoning addresses or implies the rule that a store employee’s knowledge of a spill is imputable to the store, so the case does not support that proposition.
Vaisbord v. Boston Edison Co., 304 Mass..relevant_excerpt: There was nothing in the documentary evidence, which consisted principally of the records of the various banks and the telephone company showing the opening and closing of various joint accounts and the acquisition and disposal of bank shares and stock, to warrant a finding that the husband’s estate had any interest in the accounts or the securities. The evidence did not show that the husband and wife did not freely and voluntarily enter into an arrangement which included the making of the deposits and the acquisition of the securities.

Colbert v. Ricker, 314 Mass. 138 (1943).proposition: A store employee’s knowledge of a spill is imputable to the store.
Colbert v. Ricker, 314 Mass. 138 (1943).support_reasoning: The opinion does not address store premises, employees, spills, or the imputation of an employee’s knowledge to a store. Instead, it concerns premises liability of a homeowner (a wife) to a visitor who is a business invitee of her husband, characterized as a gratuitous licensee. The case turns on the visitor’s status and the owner’s duty, not on vicarious or imputed knowledge of hazardous conditions by an employee or agent of a store.
Colbert v. Ricker, 314 Mass. 138 (1943).relevant_excerpt: "But the defendant was a gratuitous licensor and was not liable for injuries sustained by one on her premises as a business invitee of her husband. Karlowski v. Kissock, 275 Mass. 180, 183, 184. ... The plaintiff was no more than a social guest of the defendant and the latter was not liable to the plaintiff for a defect upon the premises that was due to ordinary neglect. ... The only obligation that a landowner owes to a gratuitous licensee is to refrain from wilful, wanton and reckless misconduct tending to injure the licensee."

Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuset.raw_text: Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachusetts, Inc., 418 Mass. 590 (1994)
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuset.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act despite awareness of the spill constitutes clear breach of duty under Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 and § 343A, as applied in Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachusetts, Inc., 418 Mass. 590 (1994).
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuset.support_reasoning: The opinion rejects liability because there was insufficient evidence that the defendant knew or should have known of the icy condition; it does not treat a failure to act despite awareness as a clear breach. The court focuses on lack of actual or constructive notice and ultimately holds the defendant did not violate its duty of reasonable care. Thus, Barry does not stand for the proposition that a defendant’s failure to act despite awareness of a spill (or similar hazard) constitutes a clear breach under Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 343 and 343A; rather, it underscores the need to prove such knowledge or opportunity to discover the condition.
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuset.relevant_excerpt: “After reviewing the evidence presented at the first trial, we conclude that the defendant’s motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict should have been allowed because the evidence, viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, was not sufficient to warrant an inference that the defendant violated the duty of reasonable care that it owed to the plaintiff… Specifically, we hold that the evidence did not warrant an inference that the defendant knew, or in the exercise of reasonable care should have known, of the icy condition that caused the plaintiff’s fall.”

Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries are within the foreseeable risks created by Defendant’s failure to maintain safe premises.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.support_reasoning: The court holds that the plaintiff’s assault was *not* reasonably foreseeable and therefore outside the scope of any duty owed by the landlord. While the opinion recognizes in general that a commercial landowner’s duty is limited to guarding against reasonably foreseeable risks of criminal acts, it expressly concludes that this plaintiff’s injuries were not within such foreseeable risks on these facts. Thus the case contradicts, rather than supports, the proposition that plaintiff’s injuries were within the foreseeable risks created by defendant’s failure to maintain safe premises.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The attack on the plaintiff was not reasonably foreseeable. There was no evidence that the landlord knew or reasonably should have known that a physical attack might occur in the building.… Here the defendant had no duty to the plaintiff to provide protection against a not reasonably foreseeable act of violence against her.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: B. Award compensatory damages in an amount to be determined at trial but believed to exceed $2,000, plus interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
